subject: Re: [junit] testing switch statements in method
msgSnippet: J.B s book is great, and I thought contains suggestions for the situation you are in. If you are working with legacy code and trying to get it under test then
messageBody:
J.B's book is great, and I thought contains suggestions for the situation
you are in.

If you are working with legacy code and trying to get it under test then the
earlier suggesion of Working Effectively With Legacy Code is probably a
must.

Just as an aside, if u are generally looking for good Java books to read, I
am reading the Head First Design Patterns book at the moment. And what a
great book! If you a reasonably new to the language and perhaps design,
this book has a lot of information in it. It sort of reminds me (in some
ways) to the content of Robert C. Martin's Agile Software Development book
(another great read BTW) ... but I think a bit easier to read.

HTH
Shane

On 3/8/06, Kamal Ahmed <KAhmed@...> wrote:
>
> Dear Todd,
>
>
>
> I am reading the following books, but maybe not as fast as you would
> expect
> me to.
>
>
>
> 1. JUnit Recipes, By J.B Raisenberger
> 2. Pragmatic Unit Testing in Java with JUnit, by Andrew Hunt and
> David
> Thomas
> 3. JUnit in Action, by Vincent Massol
> 4. Extreme Programming with Ant, by Niemeyer Poteet.
>
>
>
> I would welcome any suggestions, by you as well. My Java experience is
> only
> school, and 3 months at my previous job. So if my questions are at a level
> lower then you would expect to see,
>
> Then please let me know, I'll look elsewhere. And I do appreciate your
> criticism, I will look more into the books first before asking any
> question.
>
>
>
> Thanks,
>
> -Kamal.
>
>
>

> > option, so he's definitely looking for an option to test an
> > API that he has no control over. Sad, but fairly common in
> > my opinion.
> >
> > It's already been done, but I'll repeat it: Michael
> > Feather's book "Testing legacy code" contains some good
> > advice for these kinds of situations
>
> I don't believe we have any evidence that Kamal has
> ever purchased and read any of the testing related
> books already recommended to him in the past on this
> list. So, your recommendation will likely fall on
> deaf ears.
>
>
> Todd.
